Article Title: "Slap in my face": Cam Newton vents frustration as Colts turn to 44-year-old Philip Rivers
Article Text:
Cam Newton fumes after Colts bring back Philip Rivers instead of giving him a shot (Getty Images)

Cam Newton calls Colts decision a ‘slap to my face’



The NFL spent the week buzzing after the Indianapolis Colts decided to call 44-year-old Philip Rivers, a man who has not taken a snap since 2020. The move surprised fans, analysts and even former players. But no reaction stood out more than Cam Newton’s, who admitted the decision left him puzzled and a little offended. Newton said he had been open to opportunities, had stayed in shape and had never closed the door on football. Yet his phone did not ring.Newton shared his frustration on his podcast, speaking with the kind of candor he usually saves for his closest circle. He said the signing made him rethink how teams decide who gets a second chance and who gets left waiting. It pulled back the curtain on the complicated judgments teams make, and it revealed how deeply players feel these decisions, even long after their peak years.Newton made his feelings known on his latest episode of the “4th&1” podcast. He said the Rivers workout did not bother him because Rivers is a rival or a peer. It bothered him because of what it suggested about how teams viewed him. “For 44 years old, coming out of retirement…It’s almost like a slap in my face,” he said.Newton made it clear he would have accepted a workout immediately if the Colts had reached out.His co-host asked whether Newton’s growing media presence might confuse teams about his interest in returning. Newton rejected the idea. “Did Philip Rivers send any type of signs that he was available?” he said. “Why you asking me to do something that everybody else didn't do. I ain't no sucka, I ain't no lab rat.” He added that people often expect him to meet standards they never apply to anyone else. “People be holding people to a standard that they ain't even hold anybody else to that standard. ”To show he has stayed ready, Newton pointed fans toward his Snapchat, where he frequently posts his workouts. He contrasted that with Rivers, who had fully stepped away. Newton lightened the mood by joking about their shared reputation for having large families. “That’s from my brother from another that got's a lot of sisters and brothers that came from his scrotum,” Newton said. “He's got a lot of kids like me!”The Colts will learn soon whether their gamble pays off. Rivers is expected to suit up when Indianapolis travels to Seattle on Sunday. Newton, meanwhile, left the door wide open. “Call my boy, man. Reach out to us. We taking workouts… we taking chances,” he said. He closed with a final message that carried more weight than anger. “I want to be who really want me. If you don’t want me, don’t send for me.”Also Read: As Patrick struggles on field, Brittany Mahomes turns heads in stunning all-white look with surprise twist
Article Summary: Cam Newton calls Colts decision to bring back Philip Rivers a ‘slap to my face’ Newton said he had been open to opportunities, had stayed in shape and had never closed the door on football. He said the signing made him rethink how teams decide who gets a second chance.

Article Title: Nicki Minaj vs. Cardi B feud takes political twist as JD Vance jumps in with unexpected praise

Nicki Minaj vs Cardi B feud deepens as Vance enters the spotlight



The political world woke up to an unexpected twist when Vice President JD Vance stepped into a music rivalry that has dominated rap culture for years. His late night post on X instantly stirred reactions across politics, entertainment and social media. The moment felt surreal to many users, who watched a sitting vice president join a feud known for its sharp lyrics, bold personalities and a history of public clashes. It marked a rare moment where Washington’s attention drifted into hip hop’s most persistent rivalry.People rushed to screenshot Vance’s post before the conversation grew louder across the platform. The vice president wrote, “Nicki > Cardi,” in response to a now deleted message from Nicki Minaj. The comment spread quickly, not just because of the bluntness, but because it placed a top elected official directly into an argument that fans have fueled for nearly a decade.Minaj’s deleted post appeared to read “Vance > Rants,” based on screenshots that circulated before she removed it. No one knows what sparked it, but it matched the playful tone of the posts still live on her account. She followed up with more lines aimed at Vance, including “Vance > Ants in the pants,” paired with a smiling photo of 50 Cent.A short time later she added, “The Vance > The Gav Nots,” and then praised the growing meme storm. Those details have not been supported by reporting, yet her reposts drew wide attention. She also shared a video of Trump performing the well known “Trump dance” and captioned it, “Mood. ”While Vance’s comment sparked headlines, the underlying feud between Minaj and Cardi has run since 2017. Even after moments of calm, the tension returned through subtle jabs and eventually a heated exchange online earlier this year.Their differences extend beyond music. And his leadership on the global stage in calling for urgent action to defend Christians in Nigeria and to combat extremism and to bring a stop to violence against those who simply want to express their natural right to freedom of religion or belief. ”Vance’s short post linked politics, culture and celebrity drama in a way few expected. What began as a simple message may now grow into a much larger conversation as fans and lawmakers react to a feud that refuses to fade.Also Read: Patriots QB Drake Maye settles fan confusion, revealing the real name everyone should use for wife Ann Michael

Article Title: Why did Denver Broncos decide to waive oldest tight end Marcedes Lewis just after 4 appearances
Article Text:
(Image Source - Getty Images)

Why Denver Broncos considered the waiving of Marcedes Lewis

The Denver Broncos waived veteran tight end Marcedes Lewis on Thursday, December 11, 2025, less than a week after his most recent game appearance. At the age of 41, Lewis had just become the oldest tight end in NFL history a month prior, celebrating a significant achievement in his 20th year in the league.This move is seen as procedural and creates a roster spot as the Broncos get ready for their Week 15 clash with the Green Bay Packers on Sunday, with several players returning from injuries. Lewis may not have recorded any stats, but his time on the field as a blocker showed just how much the team needs depth at tight end during this challenging time.The Broncos decided to waive Lewis due to a mix of roster management and players coming back from injuries.
